html_content:
1. Rumored Trump Trip to Scottish Golf Course Ruled Out of Bounds

    Scotland’s first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has shot down a supposed plan for the president to pass the Biden inauguration at his Turnberry links.

    By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

    Jan. 5, 2021

  2. Vaccine Rollouts in Europe Are Off to a Shaky Start, Even as Lockdowns Expand

    Programs in many countries have been hampered by slow-moving bureaucracies, a lack of nurses and shortages of vital equipment.

    By Marc Santora

    Jan. 5, 2021

  3. It’s Mother vs. Son in Britain’s Priciest Divorce War

    Tatiana Akhmedova is trying to recoup part of a $615 million judgment owed by her ex-husband by suing her elder child, who she says has been shielding his father’s assets.

    By David Segal

    Jan. 5, 2021

  4. It Spied on Soviet Atomic Bombs. Now It’s Solving Ecological Mysteries.

    Imagery from the Cold War’s Corona satellites is helping scientists fill in how we have changed our planet in the past half century.

    By Marion Renault

    Jan. 5, 2021

  5. Profiles in Science

    Inside the C.I.A., She Became a Spy for Planet Earth

    Linda Zall is disclosing how she toiled anonymously within the intelligence agency to help scientists intensify their studies of a changing planet.

    By William J. Broad

    Jan. 5, 2021

  6. Britain, Trump, Coronavirus: Your Tuesday Briefing

    Here’s what you need to know.

    By Victoria Shannon

    Jan. 4, 2021

  7. Gerry Marsden, a Hitmaker With the Pacemakers, Dies at 78

    For a time in the early ’60s, with songs like“Ferry Cross the Mersey,” “Don’t Let the Sun Catch You Crying” and “You’ll Never Walk Alone,” the Pacemakers rivaled the Beatles.

    By Jim Farber

    Jan. 4, 2021

  8. TimesVideo

    It’s Back to Lockdown for Britain as Cases Soar

    Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressing Britons on Monday.

    By The Associated Press

    Jan. 4, 2021

  9. TimesVideo

    Scotland Will Go Into Lockdown After Coronavirus Variant Spread

    Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, announced on Monday that the country will go back into lockdown until the end of January due to the increase of coronavirus cases from a newly discovered variant.

    By The Associated Press

    Jan. 4, 2021

  10. Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot Approve a Merger They Need to Survive

    Shareholders of the two companies voted to join forces in an effort to cope with a major technology shift and plummeting sales.

    By Jack Ewing

    Jan. 4, 2021

  11. Britain Re-enters Sweeping Lockdown as Virus Variant Rages

    Prime Minister Boris Johnson closed schools and declared a national lockdown in England, following on the heels of Scotland.

    By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler

    Jan. 4, 2021

  12. Trump’s Call Leaves Allies Fearful for American Democracy

    Many now take the president’s disregard for democratic and ethical norms for granted, but also fear its effect on America’s standing in the world.

    By Steven Erlanger

    Jan. 4, 2021

  13. Rescuers Search for Survivors in Norway Landslide That Killed at Least 7

    Seven bodies have been recovered following the disaster last week in a village north of Oslo. Three people are still missing.

    By Henrik Pryser Libell and Isabella Kwai

    Jan. 4, 2021

  14. Italy Dispatch

    Without Tourism, Life in a Tuscan Village Slides Back in Time

    The sharp drop in visitors since the start of the pandemic pressed this small community in the hills of Chianti to cling to the essentials: the pharmacy, the food store and agriculture.

    By Gaia Pianigiani

    Jan. 4, 2021

    15. Advertisement

    Continue reading the main story

  15. Iran Increases Uranium Enrichment at Key Nuclear Facility

    The move is another a series of escalations with the United States. In another provocation, the country seized a South Korean chemical tanker.

    By Marc Santora

    Jan. 4, 2021

  16. U.K. Judge Blocks Assange’s Extradition to U.S., Citing Mental Health

    U.S. officials want the WikiLeaks founder to face charges of violating the Espionage Act. But a judge in London ruled that he was at extreme risk of suicide.

    By Elian Peltier and Megan Specia

    Jan. 4, 2021

  17. Britain, Trump, Covid-19: Your Monday Briefing

    Here’s what you need to know.

    By Victoria Shannon

    Jan. 3, 2021

  18. Biden Plans Renewed Nuclear Talks With Russia While Punishing Kremlin, Adviser Says

    The president-elect also plans to pursue a “follow-on negotiation” with Iran over its missile capabilities if Tehran re-enters compliance with the nuclear deal.

    By David E. Sanger

    Jan. 3, 2021

  19. Un an de scandales et de réflexion pour l’édition française

    Depuis la publication du “Consentement”, le milieu littéraire est sur la sellette, aux prises avec un pays auquel il ressemble de moins en moins.

    By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut

    Read in English

    Jan. 3, 2021

  20. A Year of Scandals and Self-Questioning for France’s Top Publishers

    The release of “Consent” put France’s literary establishment under a harsh spotlight. The publishing industry is grappling with a nation that it resembles less and less.

    By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut

    Lire en français

    Jan. 3, 2021
